Idled this game until I had enough time on it to write a review.

This game is a shameless, blatant knockoff of slither.io. Don't get me wrong, there's nothing wrong with getting ideas from something else and basing your ideas on it, but at least add some new mechanics. They added some mechanics and new elements to the table, but, unfortunately, they're pretty bad.

First, there's Free For All. It's basically how slither.io already is. They couldn't even copy that correctly. The game is buggy as can be, with the hitboxes for the heads being miniscule, hitting things when you know that you weren't even touching, and sometimes being able to phase through other worms completely. One mechanic that is completely unacceptable is the fact that there is a limit on how big you can get. On a game about becoming huge, this is practically a sin.

There are some small things that make this game particularly unenjoyable. For example, when you first start the game, it prompts you to leave a good rating for the game to get 100 coins. That's a stupid way to get positive reviews for such a watered down game. Another small thing is the music. While I know you can just turn it off in the settings and play some stuff from your computer, I just have to complain about this. When you start up, you're blasted with sh-tty dubstep. You also have to make an account for this game (no, you can't connect to your Steam account like a normal game, you actually have to make a screen name and password), so that's pretty bad.

Basic Overview
Pros:
Free, small download
Simple graphics, pretty accessible

Cons:
Blatant knockoff of slither.io
Bad gamemodes
Bad dumbstep music
Sign up

Final Verdict:This game is just straight booboo.

reviewText:
After putting over 4 hours into the game it I've reached the conclusion that it's trying and failing to be too many things at once.

The controls go funky on me quite a lot.  I have swung my mouse to the right going straight up and it registered as a left loop, which got me killed running into someone. My dash has also been locked in the on position, making a quick boost become an uncontrollable skid into 3 other players.  I would chalk this up to a fluke, but it kept happening.

The arenas are super tiny.  While this encourages action to take place, it is so small that new players have barely any time to collect mass before having 5 other new players fling themselves at you hoping to score quick mass.

Very bad hit boxes. While other games like Slither.io have a small hit box on the very tip of your snake, Worm.is's hit box is the entirety of your head. Two snakes smashing heads in a straight line, the one with the most mass automatically wins. Very frustrating when trying to make any progress in the game, since a larger worm hitting you will most likely also hit your head, in which the most mass rule applies and you pop.  So how do you kill larger worms?  By stealing from Agar.io and putting buzz saws around the arena that you can shoot mass into. After a few shots they become fly off in the direction that you hit it with.  This has worked ONCE in all the times I tried, since it has to hit the center of the head to kill the worm. Not to even mention if any other player sees you trying to do it you'll immediately be attacked since you are shooting points out of your body for them to collect. (And they will see you since as I said the arenas are tiny.)

So how do you get quick and easy mass?  My best tactic to gain 40k mass was to go along the edge for the first few minutes (since the boundaries are hard barriers and will kill you if you so much as look at them for very long) to gain enough mass to begin going into a circle and watch as other players throw themselves at me and collect  the mass as I go around. Since I won head on collisions I just sat there and kept going around until a new player spawned in with invincibility and kept his tail on my nose when it went away, killing me.

Chat is also questionable, since half of the chat messages were just spawned players begging the top 3 to team up so they give them mass and the other half was people complaining about newbs stealing the mass of people they killed.

Hunger games was a novel idea, but after waiting a half hour for a second game to load and only having 8/20 players, I gave up on playing it more than once.

Finally, going back to the mass shooting... Why on earth make that the default left click?  It's a bad feature in the first place, making it what's the default dash button in Slither is just asinine.

Can this game be salvaged? Loosen up the hit boxes, open the arenas a bit and remove the stupid mass shooting and it could be more fun. As it stands now? I'll just go back to slither.io

reviewText:
Despite many complaining about this game being a blatant rip-off (which it is) of Slither.io, it functions relatively well for the purpose it serves.

I've dealt with very little issues regarding gameplay. I didn't note overly large hitbox, which many reviewers have stated. In fact, they're relatively fair and decently sized. What I found was a shame was that you can't really wrap yourself around other players once you reach a certain length. In fact you practically have to be on the leaderboard in order to achieve that.

Also, no, you don't need to pay for anything in order to turn the music off. Despite it being repetitive, I found the music choices to be quite fitting to the game, but that's just me. So if you like chiptunes and Amagamaguchi sounding music, there's nothing to worry about.

What I really like is the ability to spit out a bit of your mass. I found that it's a good way to bait others to get in kills and gain mass efficiently, so the strategy is certainly there, you just need to execute it.

I experienced some lag spikes as well, but they weren't frequent enough to be a huge issue for me. In fact I dealt with more lag issues in Slither.io and Agar.io than this game, so there's something to consider.

If you're looking to get this game, just like Slither.io, it's free, so the only thing you'll lose if you try this out is time and memory space.

It has been made apparent by many reviews that this is a copy of Slither.io. I played worm.is first and subsequently played slither.io so I will compare both games.

The hitbox detection is much better in worm.is, with little ambiguity when you run into somebody. It never feels like you've been cheated, whereas in slither.io this is often the case as the hitboxes are smaller than the worms themselves.

There is significantly less lag and stutter in worm.is than slither.io. The ability to choose server is also nice.

One downside is that the pace of the game feels slower in worm.is, the acceleration of the worms is just not very fast. slither.io definitely feels more fast paced. Additionally, the map still feels rather small compared to slither.io.

I started playing after the May 7th update, so perhaps this has fixed many of the issues which older reviews have mentioned.

reviewText:
This game offers a very similar experience to the Slither.io in many respects. However, I am not going to rate it down based upon its obvious similarities to Slither. Many of the negative reviews I’ve seen rate the game poorly, simply based upon its similarity to Slither. This logic is frankly, cofounding. Yes, Worm.Is is practically a clone of Slither, however invitation to a good idea is not a reason to belittle it. Under that logic, you should never say or think anything that has been said or thought by anyone else before you, or you’re copying them.

To degrade a game, based upon the logic, “It looks like something I have seen before,” without offering any actual solid reasons for why you did or did not enjoy the game itself, is well, confounding and small minded. Think, form ideas, conceptualize. Is the game a rip off, yes, does that make it bad, absolutely not. Almost everything is a rip off of something else. “Good artists copy. Great artists steal.”

That being said, I don’t mind that the game is obviously a rip off. The game incorporates different ideas and greater complexity, allowing for many features not currently available in Slither.io. Some of these features include, team battles, the ability to add and play with your friends, actual objectives which make the game feel meaningful, purchasable skins via collection of in game currency, many more game modes and an overall improved complexity. I have played Slither, and personally enjoy the features that this game offers over that of Slither in its current state. It simply has more to offer.

Some of the cons are: The detection hit boxes are very wanky and at times unpredictable, the graphics style could use some improvement, there are still many optimization issues with lag, changes need to be made to the inviting players system, the maps could use increased complexity, as well as many other bugs and glitches that those of you who play are certainly aware of.

Overall, it's an enjoyable experience, and it's free...If you don't like it, then don't play it.

reviewText:
I played this without knowing about the slither.io, and found it very fun and addicting. I then learned about slither and agar.io.

While blatent IP theft is usually something you see on a mobile platform store, I guess it had to happen eventually on steam.

On the other hand, I can't actually play agar.io due to the horrible lag. I can't tell how good the original is since it's unplayably laggy, but I can play and enjoy mitos.is and worm.is.

Until the original games get better server capacity, I guess I'll play this steam clone. But I won't be buying any coins.

That is one small plus, the worm.is games give you plenty of game currency in the normal course of play. I've bought half a dozen skins, including the really expesive ones, just from swallowing coins during play.

I'm torn about wether to give the game thumbs up or down.

If the publisher hadn't bribed me to give them a rating with free game currency, I wouldn't have known it was a rip off, and ironically would have been quite happy with the game.

On that basis, I suppose I'll give it a recommendation. But only just.
